Meet Hank. Hank is a life-long farmer who has been working on his family farm in Alabama for the majority of his 62 years. Back in 2015, his hands got stuck in a hay baler and he lost his right hand. Before the ACA, Hank's family hadn't had health coverage since the 1980s. His ACA policy ended up covering his entire hospital bill, which he says could have cost him his farm if he hadn't had insurance. Hank is just one of 213,000 Alabamians who have gained coverage under the ACA and millions more who have benefited.   As with any law, the ACA isn't perfect but rather than repealing the law, we need to work together to stabilize the market and increase access. Stories like Hank's remind us why our work to make health insurance affordable and accessible has never been more important. My congressional district is full of people who, like my constituents who have called today, work full-time jobs and rely on programs like the ACA for their health insurance.   We must stand up for these hard-working families.

This Women’s History Month, I want to honor some of the extraordinary women leaders from our state. Today, I’m recognizing Helen Keller, who overcame challenges of deafness and blindness to learn braille and communicate with the speaking world. Helen Keller is an Alabama-native, who changed the world’s understanding of what it means to be disabled.

Today in Women’s History Month, I’m recognizing Mae Jemison, the first African American woman to travel into space. In 1992, Jemison went into orbit aboard the Space Shuttle Endeavor where she conducted medical research. Born in Decatur, Alabama, Jemison broke glass ceilings through her work as an astronaut with NASA.

This Women’s History Month, I want to honor some of the extraordinary women leaders from our state. Today, I’m recognizing Harper Lee, author of To Kill a Mockingbird. Through her writing, Harper Lee, highlighted issues of racial inequality for a nationwide audience, and helped to shine a light on the injustice that African Americans and other minorities face.

Today in Women’s History Month, I’m recognizing Coretta Scott King. King was an outspoken advocate for African-American equality who helped to lead the civil rights movement following her husband’s assassination. King’s work as an advocate not only helped to cement the victories of the civil rights movement, but also helped to protect the legacy Dr. Martin Luther King.

I want to take a moment this Women’s History Month to recognize Rosa Parks, one of our nation’s civil rights heroes and an Alabama native.  Rosa Parks took a bold stand against racial discrimination by refusing to give up her seat on a public bus. Her quiet, dignified courage didn’t just spark a city-wide boycott, but helped to inspire a civil rights movement that changed a nation.

Today in Women’s History Month, I’m recognizing Maud McLure Kelly, Alabama’s first woman lawyer and a tireless advocate for women’s rights. Kelly helped to lead the Birmingham Equal Suffrage Association in its campaign to give women the right to vote, and later became a federal attorney for the Department of the Interior. Maud McLure Kelly was a trailblazer who remains an inspiration today.

This Women’s History Month, I want to honor some of the extraordinary women leaders from our state. Today, I’m recognizing American novelist and Alabama native Zora Neale Hurston. Among her many works, Hurston wrote Their Eyes Were Watching God, an iconic piece of American literature that celebrates rural, southern life in African American communities.

This Women's History Month, I'm recognizing trailblazing women from Alabama who have helped to shape the world. Today, I want to recognize Condoleezza Rice, our first African-American woman Secretary of State. Born in Birmingham, Alabama, Secretary Rice not only shaped foreign policy but helped to pave the way for future women leaders.

For decades, protecting voting rights was a bipartisan issue. But since the Supreme Court gutted the Voting Rights Act, new threats have emerged endangering our right to vote. Here's my take:

Restoring voter protections isn't going to easy in today's political environment, but that's why we have to speak up. We cannot be silent in the face of discrimination, we cannot give in to adversity.

Four years ago today, the Supreme Court gutted the Voting Rights Act in Shelby County v. Holder. Since then, states across the country have cut polling places and hours, enacted new voter ID laws, and gerrymandered congressional districts in a way that deprives minority voters of a fair voice in our elections. That's not how democracy is supposed to work, and that's why we're fighting back.  Voting is a fundamental right, and it's our job to protect that right. It's time for Congress to act, and that means restoring the Voting Rights Act. We need action now!

As we recognize today's anniversary of the Supreme Court's decision to gut the Voting Rights Act, it's important to remember the sacrifices that heroes like Rep. John Lewis made to enact that historic legislation. They spilled blood for our right to vote, and we cannot let that right slip away.   We stand on the shoulders of our nation's voting rights heroes, but it's time for us to carry out the fight for democracy. We have a responsibility to act.

Lives are saved at our rural hospitals.   Many of our Wilcox County constituents have written in to tell me how important J Paul Jones Hospital has been to them and their families over the years. But only the hospital could cope with the stabbing victims Dr. Paul saw too often. Two of my classmates had hepatitis one year and were kept comfortable and isolated at the new hospital.  Black and white, old and young, rich or poor, brave or scared, all could be patched up and sent home to live to tell about their scars, usually.  Some did not recover.  But all received the same quality level of care. Future generations should have MORE, not less. Please save the little hospital that could!"  I will be sharing more stories in the coming days from Wilcox County, where the county's sole hospital is scheduled to close at the end of the month. We must all work together on a solution.

A mother in Camden wrote me about what John Paul Jones hospital has meant to her family. #SaveJPaulJones  "I have called our facility a "Band-Aid station" more often than I should. At the time, we actually did not know that was what had bit her. Being that we didn't know, & judging by how fast her swelling had begun & discoloration we did NOT hesitate to rush her to our local hospital. Upon arrival the staff did not waste a minute to get her into the back & try to figure out what was going on. When the doctor came in, he didn't frighten us, but let us know quickly that he was going to call for lifeflight immediately. They began some blood work & got her as comfortable as possible until the air lift arrived. My daughter was sent to Children's & it was ruled as a copperhead bite. Had we the only option to drive 45 minutes or more to the next nearest facility, things could have (been) much worse. We NEED our facility to remain open. The nearest facility to us is nearly an hour away, in any direction from Camden. Please, we need our hospital."

While GOP leadership are celebrating passage of the #GOPTaxScam with their donors, I'm getting calls from parents in Alabama who are worried that their kids will lose insurance because of the expiration of the Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), or ALL Kids, as it's known in Alabama. This is unconscionable.  GOP leaders are refusing to reauthorize CHIP without cutting funds for other health programs. That is nonsense. I just watched them vote for a wealthy tax cut that raises the national debt by $1.5 trillion.  I've been calling  for an extension of CHIP for months. But even after it expired, the Ways and Means Committee refused to hold a hearing. Instead, they spent time writing a tax bill for the wealthy. We need to reauthorize CHIP now. Not by slashing other healthcare programs, not at the end of the week, and not next month. This isn't about politics, it's about children's access to healthcare. We have to extend CHIP now!

TAX BILL UPDATE: The bill the House passed yesterday broke congressional rules, so we are re-voting today. Another example of the rushed, haphazard way this Congress has taken on legislative changes which will impact 100% of our economy.

It is unconscionable that Republican leaders are willing to throw away $1.5 trillion on tax cuts for special interests when they aren’t willing to extend funding for the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), or ALL Kids as it’s known in Alabama. For a tenth of what this tax bill costs, Congress could have stopped CHIP from expiring and saved healthcare for millions of children. Instead, families in my district may be getting ALL Kids cancellation notices for Christmas. Children’s lives are at risk, but Republican leaders have prioritized tax cuts for the wealthy.  To Alabama families and all those who depend on CHIP for children's healthcare coverage, please know that I will keep fighting for a vote on CHIP! This should be a top priority in Congress.
